Posts.Content: Thanks guys for catching the mistake in my signature. I have corrected it. At one point husband was considering surgery but has ruled it out it favor of radiation. Radiation will start soon but if he agrees to Lupron will need to wait a few months for that to take effect first.
Posts.Signature: Husband (Age 59) 1st PSA 2/25/15: 11.4, DRE Positive Biopsy: 3/25/15, G9, 14 of 14 cores positive with 60% to 80% SV Positive, Two nodes showing on MRI, Bone scan clear Casodex: 4/8/15 to 5/20/15 Early chemo: 6 sessions from 5/20/15 to 9/16/15 Radiation planned to begin 11/2015 Vit D, Calcium, Green Tea Extract, Resveratrol, Curcumin, Lycopene, Soy Isoflavones, Claritin
Posts.Title: Help! Would it be crazy to decline HT???

Posts.Content: My husband is a G9 with 12 of 12 cores postive, SV positive and two nodes visible on the MRI. His PSA at diagnosis was 11.4 in 3/2015. He just completed the new early chemo protocol and his PSA is down to 8.4 and is probably still dropping. The recent scans show shrinkage of the cancer. Obviously this is a very serious diagnosis. Our next step is to move onto Lupron and then radiation. We are EXTREMELY hesitant about the HT. The doctor says he only has a 35% to 40% chance of being biochemical reoccurence free at 5 years. And wants husband to go on 2 to 3 years of HT. We are a very loving, sexually active couple and we know that this could be the end of our sex life and the beginning of other really negative HT side effects. Since the odds of the cancer reoccuring is very high anyway, why should he go on HT now and lose his quality of life?? What would be wrong with just doing radiation now and having the next 2 to 3 years to fully enjoy and then going on HT if and when there is a reoccurence. I feel like I'm losing my mind over this and could really use some advice. Thank you.
Posts.Signature: Husband (Age 59) 1st PSA 2/25/15: 11.4, DRE Positive Biopsy: 3/25/15, G9, 14 of 14 cores positive with 60% to 80% SV Positive, Two nodes showing on MRI, Bone scan clear Casodex: 4/8/15 to 5/20/15 Early chemo: 6 sessions from 5/20/15 to 9/16/15 Radiation planned to begin 11/2015 Vit D, Calcium, Green Tea Extract, Resveratrol, Curcumin, Lycopene, Soy Isoflavones, Claritin

Posts.Title: Help! Would it be crazy to decline HT???

Posts.Content: Like me, many of you have purchased and read Dr. Patrick Walsh's book "Surviving Prostate Cancer." In fact, I've heard many of you refer to it as the PC bible. I read with interest the section on Hormone Therapy. Dr. Walsh says he is in the camp of doctors who believe hormone therapy should begin at clinical progression (metastasis) versus earlier. He states that HT does not change OS so why not save it for later and preserve your quality of life while you can. He claims HT is only controlling the hormone sensitive cancer while the non-hormone sensitive cancer is getting stronger and progession will happen at about the same time anyway. I'm curious whether the book is current about this because you usually hear of people starting it much sooner. Thoughts?
Posts.Signature: Husband (Age 59) 1st PSA 2/25/15: 11.4, DRE Positive Biopsy: 3/25/15, G9, 14 of 14 cores positive with 60% to 80% SV Positive, Two nodes showing on MRI, Bone scan clear Casodex: 4/8/15 to 5/20/15 Early chemo: 6 sessions from 5/20/15 to 9/16/15 Radiation planned to begin 11/2015 Vit D, Calcium, Green Tea Extract, Resveratrol, Curcumin, Lycopene, Soy Isoflavones, Claritin
Posts.Title: Is Dr. Walsh's book current on early vs late hormone therapy?

Posts.Content: Husband had his first biopsy today. The urologist noted that he could see a fair amount of calcification on the ultra sound. And he also noted that this could explain husband's PSA of 11. Unfortunately it will take another week to find out. So my question to all of you is did most of you have calcification in addition to your cancer? Or do the two conditions usually exist independent of each other? PS -- Per my other thread, we will be switching doctors once we get the results. Husband did not want to wait another month to get in with another doc.
Posts.Title: How many of you had calcification?

Posts.Content: Lancepeace: We are from the Midwest. Michael: I tried to get my husband into a couple of other Urologists in town but they said it would take 4 to 6 weeks. Then we tried to see another Urologist in the same practice as our current Uro but they would did not return our calls . . . probably because it was a conflict of interest since we had already started with his partner. We just could not stomach the thought of six more weeks of waiting without finding something out. The biopsy went fine but we know we will not continue with this doc. We are going to get the results either this Friday or next Monday then we are planning on getting referred to the Mayo Clinic -- no matter how the results come out.
Posts.Title: How many of you had calcification?

Posts.Content: As my husband (a G9) and I prepare for his first Lupron shot next week, we realize that we are saying goodbye to sex as we knew it. But, even though it was a wonderful part of our marriage, I am very willing to do this in order to keep him around. As I have read, hormone therapy means a loss of libdo and impotence. But does loss of libdo also mean he won't care to be touched, kissed, etc? Does it mean that if he wants to please me that he will be counting the minutes til it's over? For those of you who have been through hormone therapy, how did you feel about non-intercourse sexual interactions? Did you cease to have romantic feelings altogether?
Posts.Title: What does loss of libido truly mean?

Posts.Content: My husband, who is a G9 T3bN with a PSA of 11.4, was just diagnosed a month ago. We have since seen four doctors -- a Uro, a Uro/Surgeon, a Radiation Oncologist, and now a Medical Oncologist. Because my husband is only 59 and in otherwise very good health, all four docs are recommending surgery. Currently he is just on Casodex. Two of the four docs have mentioned some new trials/studies which suggest that newly diagnosed men with high-risk disease can get a huge leg up with a protocol of docetaxel and lupron PRIOR (neoadjuvant) to surgery or radiation. I have not seen any mention of this on this forum but I have read the studies. It is very encouraging and a direction I think we will go. Anyone else heard of this or done this?
Posts.Title: Pre-surgery chemo recommended

Posts.Content: Hey George. Not sure if I noted it correctly or not but my husband's MRI is showing two enlarged nodes. Is T3bN the proper way to say this or should it be T3bN2? But yes, this is a new "pushing the envelope" approach. I am very impressed with the Sloan Kettering-trained medical oncologist who recommended this to us. And it's been ok'd by our Mayo doc who said, of course, there are no guarantees but it will buy us more time and we have everything to gain and nothing to lose by trying it.
Posts.Title: Pre-surgery chemo recommended

Posts.Content: Yikes. If our insurance company does balk at this then we may have to back pedal. We would not have the money to pay for this on our own. We will know more on Tuesday. We have a in-depth meeting with the oncologist then. So far we have only had a long phone consult with him after he received our records. We have to travel a ways to get there. Fairwind, the Mayo surgeon put him on Casodex when we were thinking we were going to have surgery within the next 3-4 weeks. But when we consulted with him on this new approach he did not say anything about the stickiness issue.
Posts.Title: Pre-surgery chemo recommended

Posts.Content: Hey George. Not sure if I noted it correctly or not but my husband's MRI is showing two enlarged nodes. Is T3bN the proper way to say this or should it be T3bN2? But yes, this is a new "pushing the envelope" approach. I am very impressed with the Sloan Kettering-trained medical oncologist who recommended this to us. Posts.Title: Pre-surgery chemo recommended

Posts.Content: A year and a half ago my then 57 year old husband (now 59) went to his urologist to get some ED meds. During that visit the doc did a DRE and noted a small nodule but did not request a PSA. He just said that he wanted to do a recheck in one year. My husband went back about 3 weeks ago and after another DRE the doc said the nodule was still there and that he now wanted to do a PSA. The results came back and the PSA was 11. We know have a biopsy scheduled in one week. I've done a lot of research and now realize how serious this could be. But I just can't believe the doctor did not request a PSA the first time around. So I'm curious to hear from all of you . . . was it very unusual for the doc not to request a PSA after feeling a nodule?? And even then to ask for such a long recheck time?? I'd appreciate your insights!
Posts.Title: Did husband's doctor make a big mistake?

Posts.Content: Thank you all for confirming my suspicions about this being a doctor error . . . a very big one in my opinion. When I go with my husband to the biopsy next week I plan to make my feelings known to the doctor. And then we will probably switch to someone new. From what my husband says, he is young. But still he should know better. His mistake could potentially cost my husband's life. If this turns out to be bad news I think I will probably take my complaint above his head. Several had asked about previous PSAs . . . no, he had never had one before.

Posts.Title: Did husband's doctor make a big mistake?

Posts.Content: My newly diagnosed G9 husband (age 59) has decided to go the new early chemo route before surgery. He just had his second infusion the other day. Back in January, before the DX, we noticed that he had a large hard lump under his skin on the top of his thigh. It was about 6 inches below his hip bone. With all of the the trauma of the diagnosis we kind of forgot about it. Then after his first round of chemo we have noticed that it has almost completely disappeared. While some might say this is good, I am worried that this might be a metastasis. His MRI did show two nodes as suspicious in the pelvic region but his bone scan was clean. We asked the oncologist about it the other day and he said without doing a biopsy it's hard to know what it is and that it would not change our current course of treatment. He wants hubby to do CT scans after the next round of chemo. My question to all of you is have you ever heard of anything like this relating to PC? Or could it be another type of cancer? If it is prostate cancer, I would think that this would take surgery off the table, meaning that it is now systematic. (Just entered my signature today; hope it shows up) Any insights would be much appreciated!!!

Posts.Title: Lump in upper thigh reacting to early chemo. Is it metastasis?

Posts.Content: Thank you all for your thoughts! I'm probably just borrowing trouble where I should not be. If anything it is encouraging that it shrunk so quickly after just one cycle of chemo. I'm hoping the prostate and pelvic nodes are shrinking at an equal pace.

Posts.Title: Pre-surgery chemo recommended

Posts.Content: Thanks Chuck. I should clarify . . . the docs just referenced the trials as evidence that this new approach can work . . . but he would not be in a trial. He will likely start Lupron in the next 2 to 4 weeks and maybe the docetaxel shortly after. His treatment will be independent of any trial. Not sure if he will stay on Casodex but I suspect they would want him to.

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear about your dad. Do a search on a drug called Xofigo (Radium 223). It has shown good life expanding results in guys with bone cancer. Hard to say how long he has but a couple of years might be possible at this stage with these new drugs.

Posts.Content: Thank you all for your strong words of encouragement. We are meeting with the doctor tomorrow to go over the results and next steps in greater detail. We will then be scheduling with new local Uro and we will also be immediately transferring the records to Mayo Clinic.
Posts.Title: Results are back. Gleason 9.

Posts.Content: Devastated and reeling.

Posts.Title: Results are back. Gleason 9.

Posts.Content: Hello Wife in Worry, Was your husband recently diagnosed? In other words, is he doing early (neoadjuvant) chemo or is this after many other treatment protocols? My husband, a newly diagnosed G9, just finished his 3rd of 6 chemo cycles. And as we were told from the beginning, he will have a CT scan now that we are at the half way point to measure to see if the treatment is working. His PSA has been notching up instead of down. He will have surgery once chemo is done. If your husband is scheduled to have surgery or radiation they will probably do scans before those take place. What has your doctor said? What did your husband's PSA do during and after treatment?
